content: So I would say that overall, we haven't really seen any, kind of, a decline in our pro paint business, and I think that's reflective of the fact that contractors are busy, they've still got projects, they buy stuff when they feel good about the outlook on different things. One moment for your next question. One moment for your next question. We're trying to build our business in the packaging space and a really good powder equipment business, which has performed extremely well over the last couple of years, and they've got nice backlogs heading into â23. One moment for your next question. I would say that the teams over the last year have done a pretty good job of working with the corporate team in developing pipelines and looking at various applications, both with their existing markets, as well as adjacencies where we think we can drive some value. One moment for your next question. I mean, what I would tell you is that at least with regard to the home center over the last couple of years, it's been kind of crazy, right, with all the stimulus money and people working from home and hanging out at Home Depot doing projects, that kind of thing. And I would just add that in terms of the capital investment spend, the big fab investments that you read about -- and actually, we've been reading about for a couple of years now, the ones of â21 and â22, they're going to play out over the next couple of three years. One moment for your next question. Well, I would say that if we're talking EMEA on the -- I'll call it, macro data side, certainly, the economic outlook picture for Germany, which is Europe's largest industrial market, I would say, bodes -- maybe to call it a bright spot's an exaggeration, but is a favorable attribute.
